document.docAuthor: Pádua, Diego G., Sääksjärvi, Ilari E., Monteiro, Ricardo F. & Oliveira, Marcio L.
document.docTitle: Acrotaphus amazonicus Padua & Saaksjarvi 2020, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the New World genus Acrotaphus Townes, 1960 (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Pimplinae), with descriptions of fifteen new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the New World genus Acrotaphus Townes, 1960 (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Pimplinae), with descriptions of fifteen new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species can be distinguished from all other
Acrotaphus
by the combination of the following characters: 1) margin of gena behind eyes concave (flat in male) in dorsal view; 2) posterior ocelli separated from eyes by 0.3–0.5× its diameter in dorsal view; 3) metasoma orange with distal half of tergite V and tergites VI+ black or tergites V+ black; 4) hind leg entirely black, except the base of coxa orange or orange with apex of coxa, femur, tibia and tarsus black; 5) ovipositor robust, 1.3–1.5× as long as hind tibia.

Description. Female. Body [18.0] 13.0–18.0 mm. Head. Lower face [0.9] 0.8–1.0× as broad as high (from supraclypeal suture to base of antenna), flat, with scattered punctures which bear long conspicuous bristles; head in dorsal view with margin of gena concave behind eyes; margin of gena [0.5] 0.5–0.7× length of eye in dorsal view; posterior ocelli separated from eyes by [0.3] 0.3–0.5× its diameter in dorsal view. Mesosoma. Pronotum moderately long, smooth and polished, with distance from tegula to head greater than [0.5] 0.5–0.7× distance from tegula to hind margin of propodeum; mesoscutum smooth and polished, with notaulus weakly marked; scutellum in dorsal view triangular; mesopleuron polished, with fine bristles anteriorly and ventrally; epicnemial carina present ventrally, extending until reaching the level of the lower corner of the pronotum laterally; metapleuron polished, with sparse, fine bristles evenly spaced and with a strongly longitudinal groove in lower part below spiracle; propodeum smooth dorsally, laterally with scattered fine bristles. Fore wing [12.8] 10.5–13.0 mm; cu-a opposite to the base of Rs&M ; 2 rs-m [0.7] 0.6–0.9× as long as abscissa of M between 2 rs-m and 2 m-cu ; hind wing with abscissa of Cu 1 between M and cu-a [1.0]× length of cu-a . Tarsal claw with basal lobe quadrangular, with claw apex slightly overtaking the posterior margin of lobe. Metasoma. Tergite I [1.7] 1.45–1.9× as long as posteriorly broad; tergite II [1.3] 1.1–1.6× as long as posteriorly broad; tergite III [1.3] 1.1–1.6× as long as posteriorly broad; tergites IV–V [1.4] 1.0–1.4× as long as posteriorly broad; ovipositor robust, [1.6] 1.4–1.7× as long as hind tibia; lower valve with slightly swelling in the base and mid region.

Coloration. Head black, mouthparts orange, except apex of mandible black; antenna brownish. Mesosoma entirely orange. Metasoma orange, with weakly blackish marks on the posterior margin of tergites II–IV, tergite V with distal half black and tergites VI+ black.Anterior and mid leg entirely orange, the hind leg orange, with trochantellus, femur, tibia and tarsus black. Wings yellowish; fore wing with apex distal to 2 rs-m black, and with a black median band extending backwards from anterior margin, just proximal to the pterostigma, right through the 1 st subdiscal cell; pterostigma yellowish. Ovipositor brownish and sheath dark brown.

Variation. Some specimens (found from the same locality as the holotype ) have margin of gena slightly concave behind eyes; pronotum with anterior region blackish; metasoma orange with tergites V+ or VI+ black; hind coxa slightly blackish, except its base orange or coxa orange, except its apex blackish. Note: We have not treated those females and males into the paratypes . They are listed in other material .

Distribution. Brazil , Colombia , Ecuador , French Guiana , Guyana , Peru , Trinidad and Tobago ** and Venezuela ( Fig 27 ).
Etymology. The specific name refers to Amazonia.

Comments.
Acrotaphus amazonicus
sp. n.
closely resembles
A. fasciatus (Brullé, 1846)
and
A. pseudoamazonicus
sp. n.
mainly by having last metasomal tergites black and hind leg orange with femur, tibia and tarsus blackish or hind leg entirely black. It differs from
A. fasciatus
by having margin of gena behind eyes concave and posterior ocelli separated from eyes by 0.3–0.5× its diameter in dorsal view (margin of gena behind the eyes strongly concave and posterior ocelli separated from eyes by 0.1× its diameter in dorsal view in
A. fasciatus
). It differs from
A. pseudoamazonicus
sp. n.
by having margin of gena behind eyes concave (margin of gena behind eyes flat in
A. pseudoamazonicus
sp. n.
).
